p.l: Dear Mrs. Behrend:
In reference to your recent letters, I offer he following comments--
We would be most pleased to have Mr. Paul Laver from the Cemetery do certain
planting around the entrance to the Behrend Center campus. We understand
that this planting will be done by utilising the existing shrubbery in the
formal gardens. It is also my understanding that you will remimburse Mr Laven
for his labors only for the planting around the enterance and for no other plant-
ing. If you have not not already done so, I would suggest that you contact Mr. Day
informing him of your desires to have Mr. Laver do the above mentioned work.
Insofar as the new building is concerned, we do not plan ot proceed with this
project this year. We have not as yet heard from General Electric as to their
intention of us doing their training program this fall. It will be impossible at
this late date to complete any building arrangemants for the Fall term, con-
sequently we have delayed any action on a new building of this present year.
We, however, plan to spend approximatly $25,000.00 completing the other
half of the barn for utilization as classrooms.
We have located some of the lights for the living room which are in need of repair.
At the present time we will investigate the repair of these lights and I will re-
port to you at a later date as to whether or not they can be effectively repaired.
We are making arrangements to erect a wrought iron rail around the case in which
the Niagara is desplayed. Quite a few people have commented about the ship and
have visited us with the express purpose of viewing it.
Under separate cover we are sending you the television films of the presentation
of the Flagship. These films can be shown on a standard 16mm. projector.
In reference to the heating of the swimming pool, I have talked on two different
occasions with Mr. Scobell about completing the project. As yet he has done
nothing to heat the pool with the exception of having ordered a piece of equip-
ment that is needed to put the furnace in the immediate future to complete it.
In reference to the scholarships, as a result of our last Advisory Board meeting,
Mr. Nick appointed a new Scholarship Committee, consisting of Jerry Stokes, Chair-
man, William Hamilton and John Zern. I have had one meeting with Mr. Stokes and
we are planning to arrange for a number of scholarships which will be available
by September 1956. Our scholarship fund at present has been consumed so that
there is only $650.00 remaining in this fund. We have given one scholarship
to a McDowell High School student for September 1955. The scholarship fund
has not been generally advertised this year because of the small amount of
money available. We have not in the past had scholarships that were specifically
designated as Protestant scholarships. Inasmuch as we are a state university
we do not feel that it would be ethical to differentiate as to religion or
race in the issuance of a scholarship. I will keep you informed of the activities
of this committee and what prograss they make. I am quite sure that we will be
building the scholarship fund to the point where at least one scholarship will
be available to all eleven of the area high schools each year. Generally speak-
ing scholarships are in the amount of $100.00 per year, per student.
Ross P. Wright of Reed Mfg. Company has sent several copies of letters that
were supposedly written by Commodore Perry on the deck of the Ship Niagara on
the afternoon of his victory. We plan to have these copies framed and placed
in Erie Hall along with the Flagship.
I hope this letter finds you in good health and enjoying the summer. Please
give my kindest regards to Gail. Our family is well and in good health.

body.closer:
Cordially yours,
Irvin H.Kochel Administrative Head
P.S. Thanks very much for the London Illustrated News. We will put these to good use in the Library at Behrend Center.
